data.text: Contents
Purpose

The purpose of this guideline is to provide guidance on the advice and provision of contraception by practitioners in obstetrics and gynaecology, especially in the abortion and postnatal care services.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix 1)
Roles and Responsibilities

The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring clinical policies, guidelines and SOPs are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The Clinical Director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.
The Head of Midwifery, maternity matrons and maternity managers are responsible for ensuring maternity staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.
The Obstetric Clinical Lead Consultant and Labour Ward Lead Consultant are responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within the clinical setting.
All maternity staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
Background and Introduction
An estimated 19% of pregnancies are unplanned. The median age of first intercourse is 17 for both sexes. Since 1998, the under-18 conception rate for England and Wales has dropped by 51%.

Current contraceptive methods include Long-acting Reversible Contraception (LARC), hormonal methods, and oral and barrier methods. Oral contraceptives are the most commonly used, but LARC use has increased to 31% in 2013/14.

The effectiveness of oral contraceptive pills and barrier methods depend on their correct use every day or each time the person has sex. The effectiveness of LARC does not rely on correct everyday use.

Although 88% of women aged 15-44 in a heterosexual relationship report using at least one method of contraception, 185,824 abortions took place in 2015. 38% of abortions were among women who had already had one or more abortions.
Contraception after an Abortion
Healthcare practitioners should discuss contraception with women who request an abortion and should offer a choice of all methods both at assessment and at discharge
Practitioners should emphasise that women are fertile immediately after an abortion.
Postnatal Prescribing
Healthcare practitioners should give post-natal women information about, and offer a choice of, all contraceptive methods within 7 days of delivery.

Supporting women to make an informed choice about contraception after childbirth will reduce the risk of future unplanned pregnancies. Advice and information should be given as soon as possible after delivery because fertility may return quickly, including in women who are breastfeeding. Providing advice about contraception after childbirth also helps avoid the risk of complications associated with an inter-pregnancy interval of less than  months.
Discussing Contraception
When discussing contraception, give details of all contraceptive methods including:
Long-acting reversible contraceptives that need administration less than once per month:
Methods that depend on the person remembering to take or use them:
Permanent methods of contraception:

Women should be informed that no method of contraception is 100% effective and, for some methods, the efficacy is based on the correct use by the patient. However, this should be compared with the risk of pregnancy in unprotected intercourse (85% per year) and for withdrawal (22% per year).
History-taking

The method of contraception will depend on whether the woman wishes to get pregnant in the foreseeable future, whether she would benefit from additional, non-contraceptive, features of some methods (e.g. treatment for heavy menstrual bleeding, acne etc.) and her personal preference.
The following factors may affect the risk/benefit ratio of some methods:
Common Exclusions

Hormonal contraception may increase VTE risk. Systemic methods rely on liver metabolism and may be transferred to breastfed babies. Intrauterine methods will be affected by anatomy and can facilitate infection.
If in doubt, refer to the UK Medical Eligibility Criteria Guideline, or seek senior advice.
COCP is contraindicated, or of disproportionately higher risk, in:
POP is contraindicated, or of disproportionately higher risk, in:
The depot injection is contraindicated, or of disproportionately higher risk, in:
The contraceptive implant is contraindicated, or of disproportionately higher risk, in:
The copper coil is contraindicated, or of disproportionately higher risk, in:
Hormonal intrauterine systems are contraindicated, or of disproportionately higher risk, in:
Combined Oral Contraceptive Pill (COCP) ‘The Pill'

The pill contains both an estrogen and a progestogen and works by inhibiting ovulation. The pill-free/placebo week regulates menstrual bleeding. It can be used indefinitely provided that there are no contra-indications.
The pill must be taken at the same time every day:
i.  If day 1-7 use emergency contraception
f.  Start on same day as abortion or miscarriage
The pill can cause nausea, mood swings, fluid-retention and breast-tenderness (common); VTE (rare).
The pill has a failure rate of 0.3% to 9% (in first year), depending on use.
Benefits of the pill include regulation of periods, reduced bleeding, and protection against ovarian and endometrial cancer.
Prescribing
(Refer to MEHT Combined Oral Contraceptive Pathway)
a.  First line (no special considerations):
i.  Rigevidon 30/150ug (EE/LNG)
b.  Headaches (reduce estrogen):
i.  Gedarel 20/150ug (EE/DSG)
ii.  Millinette 20/75ug (EE/GSD)
c.  Mood changes or loss of libido (change progestogen):
i.  Yasmin 30/3000ug (EE/DRSP)
ii.  Cilest 35/250ug (EE/NGM)
f.  Problematic bleeding (increase estrogen or change to estradiol)
Women should have their blood pressure checked before prescribing.
The COCP should be stopped 4 weeks before elective surgery.
Progesterone-only Pill (POP) ‘The Mini Pill'
The mini pill contains a progestogen and works primarily by thickening cervical mucous. At higher doses of progestogen, ovulation may be partially inhibited.
The mini pill must be taken at the same time every day:
Bleeding with the mini pill can be unpredictable
The mini pill has a failure rate of 1.1% to 13% (in first year), depending on use
Prescribing (See MEHT Formulary):
Depot Injection
The depot is an injection that is metabolised slowly in the muscle and prevents ovulation. After 3-6 months of irregular bleeding, the depot can cause amenorrhoea (common).
Some women experience weight gain, PMS (common); reduced bone density (uncommon). Depression and acne are also observed. 50% of women stop by 1 year.
There may be a delay of menstruation up to 1 year after stopping the depot.
The depot has a failure rate of 0.2% during the first year. 0.4% over 2 years.
Prescribing:
If the dose is delayed by more than 5 days, then test for pregnancy before repeat dose and use condoms for  days after dose.
Start within first 5 days of cycle or within 5 days post-partum (unless breastfeeding).
Implant

The implant is a small plastic rod that is placed under the skin of the upper arm (under local anaesthetic) which secretes a progestogen to prevent ovulation. It may reduce bleeding, but can also cause irregular bleeds.
The implant must be replaced by a suitably-trained practitioner every 3 years.
The implant has the lowest failure rate of all contraceptives at 0.05% per year. (1:1000 per 3 years).
There is no delay to fertility when removed.
Enzyme-inducing medications (e.g. many anticonvulsants) may reduce the effectiveness.
Prescribing:
When to insert:
Intrauterine System (IUS)

The IUS is a small plastic ‘T'-shaped devices that is inserted, by a suitably-qualified practitioner, into the womb. It secretes a low dose of a progestogen to prevent implantation and can prevent fertilisation. Very little hormone is present in the circulation.

Mirena is first line treatment for Heavy Menstrual Bleeding (HMB). After 3-6 months of irregular bleeding, the Mirena coil can cause reduced bleeding (90%) or amenorrhoea (24% at 3 years). Jaydess is less likely to cause amenorrhoea (13% at 3 years).
The Mirena should be replaced every 5 years (unless fitted after the age of 45). Jaydess should be replaced every 3 years.
Complications include irregular bleeding, breast tenderness, acne and headaches (common); PID <1%, amenorrhoea (uncommon); and perforation 1:1000 (rare). 60% of women stop within 5 years.
The IUS has a failure rate of 0.2% per year (<1:100 per 5years), but has a 1:20 chance of causing an ectopic if pregnancy occurs.
Prescribing:
When to insert:
Strings should be checked 3-6 weeks after placement.
There is no delay in return to fertility after removal.
Copper Intrauterine Device (IUD)
The IUD is a small plastic ‘T'-shaped devices that is inserted, by a suitably-qualified practitioner, into the womb. It prevents fertilisation and implantation.
The coil should be replaced every 5 or  years (depending on device). It need not be replaced after the age of 40 years.
Complications include heavy irregular bleeding (common); PID <1% (uncommon); and perforation 1:1000 (rare). 50% of women stop within 5 years.
The IUD has a failure rate of 0.6% per year (<2:100 per 5 years).
Prescribing (Refer to MEHT Formulary)
When to insert:
Strings should be checked 3-6 weeks after placement.
There is no delay in return to fertility after removal.
Female Sterilisation
Tubal ligation at laparotomy, or laparoscopic placement of Filschie Clips, prevents passage of the sperm into the uterus.
Laparoscopic Sterilisation is no longer routinely funded by CCG at MEHT. Tubal ligation may be performed at Caesarean Section provided consent has been documented at least 2 weeks in advance.
Complications include regret (especially if young, childless, or relationship disharmony); injury during procedure 2:1000, laparotomy 3:1000 (uncommon); death during procedure 1:12,000 (very rare).
Failure of procedure to prevent pregnancy is 2-5:1000 at 10 years (uncommon). However, ectopic may be of greater risk if pregnancy occurs.
Male Sterilisation
Vasectomy may be performed by a suitably-qualified practitioner (including some GPs) under local anaesthetic.
Vasectomy has a failure rate of 0.1%
Barrier Methods
Barrier methods prevent the sperm from fertilising the ovum. Their efficacy depends on correct use.
The following failure rates have been observed:
Emergency Contraception

Levonorgestrel, a progestogen, is licenced for emergency contraception up to 72 hours post-coitus and is 85% effective. There is some protection up to 120 hours (not licenced). Further doses, for further exposures, in the cycle are safe. COCP/Condoms are required for the remainder of the cycle.

Ullipristal Acetate, a Selective Progesterone Receptor Modulator (SPRM), is licensed for emergency contraception up to 120 hours post-coitus. It must not be repeated within the cycle. Condoms are required for the remainder of the cycle.
a.  ellaOne  30mg (UPA)
The copper IUD is 99% effective if used within 120 hours of coitus.
Consent
Women aged  and over are presumed to have capacity to make decisions about their health (including contraception and abortion).
Women aged under  should be assessed for ‘Gillick' competency and adhere to the Fraser guidelines in respect to their capacity for decision-making. This should be clearly documented.
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy Policy and the Women's and Children's annual audit work plan. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.

The findings of the Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group report will be reported to the monthly Women's and Children's Directorate Governance Meeting and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Abortion services to be audited on:
Post-natal services to be audited on:
Staffing and Training
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes skills and drills training.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Guideline Management

22.3.1 As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be circulated clinically and professional approval confirmed by the Asset Owner prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform appropriate Maternity Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
References
NICE QS129 – Contraception – 2016
FSRH – UK Medical Eligibility Criteria for Contraceptive Use – 2010 RCOG  – Management of Premenstrual Syndrome – 2007
FSRH – Problematic Bleeding w Hormonal Contraception – 2015
NICE CG30 – Long-acting Reversible Contraception – 2005
RCOG Consent 3 – Female Sterilisation – 2016
NICE CG92 – Venous thromboembolism: Reducing risks in hospital – 2015 FSRH – Contraception for women >40 years – 2010
FSRH – Venous Thromboembolism and Hormonal Contraception – 2014 EBCG 7 – Care of Women Requesting Induced Abortion – 2011
